Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF International Research Experiences for Students program will provide support for a total of 12 Ph.D. students pursuing dissertation research in several subdisciplines of chemistry at the University of Notre Dame to do research in any of three closely aligned laboratories in Sweden. Four students will be selected each year during this three-year program to spend four summer months pursuing research on a unified theme of development of new enantioselective catalysts. Initial emphasis will be placed on catalysts for the synthesis of chiral amines, which represent a broad class of compounds of importance as pharmaceutical products, agricultural compounds, and small molecule probes in molecular biology and biochemistry. The mentors, who have collaborations amongst themselves and with Notre Dame faculty members, are Professor Per-Ola Norrby at Gothenburg University, Professor Pher Andersson at Stockholm University, and Professor Jan-Erling BÃ¤ckvall at Stockholm University. They are world leaders in the development of computational methods for prediction of enantioselectivities of chiral transition metal catalysts, the development and characterization of new metal catalysts, the evaluation of catalyst performance, and the use of molecular biology methods to develop new peptide-based catalysts. They will direct IRES student projects in these areas of specialization, blending computational studies with experimental chemistry and the tools of molecular biology to develop new transition metal- and peptide-based enantioselective catalysts. Quantum mechanics calculations will be used to define structures of transition states for selected reactions employing chiral metal catalysts. The calculated transition states will be used to generate force fields that will be applied to the in silico screening of chiral catalyst libraries to predict enantioselectivity of new or previously known catalysts in advance of their preparation and experimental validation. Molecular biology in the form of directed evolution will be employed for developing complementary peptide-based catalysts. The combination of these capabilities in the three program laboratories is unique and brings powerful new tools to bear on catalyst development. The specific IRES student projects interface well with research programs at Notre Dame and will be of interest to Ph.D. students having dissertation projects in synthetic organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, organometallic chemistry, analytical chemistry, materials science, biochemistry, and molecular biology.
The participating students will gain experience with advanced computational and experimental methods for small-molecule and polypeptide-based catalyst development. The students will present their research in an international setting, and write reports and manuscripts for publication in scientific journals. Upon returning to the Notre Dame, the participating students will be encouraged to apply their newly gained knowledge towards their dissertation research projects and, with their dissertation directors, to maintain collaborations with their Swedish mentors to pursue further aspects of their IRES projects. The collective IRES experience will prepare the participants for careers in an increasingly competitive technological world in which scientists are expected to have multiple skills and to succeed in an international setting. Moreover, students will be personally enriched from immersion in a different scientific and societal culture. In the national interest, the research outcomes of this IRES project, namely development of new enantioselective catalysts, can be translated into improved production of pharmaceuticals, agricultural agents, and chemical tools for use in biochemistry and molecular biology. These areas are long-standing strengths of the U.S., applicable to large-scale manufacturing of products for both domestic use and export. Retention of these strengths requires training of students who can contribute their expertise in an increasingly competitive, technologically based, global economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this program was to provide international research experience to Ph.D. students from the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Notre Dame by spending three to four months in the laboratories of mentors in Sweden. Experiences gained in this program served to widen the participating students’ scientific horizons beyond what would be possible in a strictly domestic environment. The host country of Sweden was chosen due to its long-standing history of doing world-leading research for more than two centuries and is the home of many of the most fundamental discoveries in the chemical sciences. The mentors were located at universities in Stockholm, Gothenburg, and Uppsala in addition to a major international pharmaceutical company, AstraZeneca. Key focus areas of the students’ research were the development of catalysts for use in the synthesis of stereochemically pure chemical products, the development of new methods in computational chemistry for prediction of outcomes of chemical reactions, improvements of enzymes for catalysis of reactions, and advanced methods in bioanalytical chemistry. The students were given additional professional enrichment opportunities, including attending scientific conferences, giving presentations on their research, writing reports and manuscripts on the results of their research, and doing a portion of their research in a high-throughput catalyst screening facility at a private/public sector research institute near Stockholm.

 

A total of 14 Ph.D. students participated during the four-year period of this program from 2014 through 2018. These students included 9 females and 5 males; 3 of these students were underrepresented minorities. The students were chosen on the basis of applications that they submitted and which were reviewed by a departmental selection committee at Notre Dame. Criteria for selections included academic records and fit of research interests and expertise with the available project areas. During the Spring Semester preceding their travel to Sweden, the selected students attended a special seminar that was conducted for two one-hour sessions each week by the Principal Investigator (PI). These sessions included basic instruction in the Swedish language, introduction to Swedish culture, and details pertaining to travel and living arrangements. During four consecutive years, three or four students traveled to Sweden in mid-May accompanied by the PI who assisted in getting the students settled into their new environments. The students returned to Notre Dame in August or September to resume their normal doctoral studies. During a no-cost extension year, one additional student travel to Sweden in August of 2018 and returned in October. The students’ mentors in Sweden were Professors Jan-Erling Bäckvall and Pher Andersson at Stockholm University, Professor Per-Ola Norrby and both Gothenburg University and AstraZeneca, and Professor Jonas Bergquist at Uppsala University. The students’ projects in Sweden were not necessarily directly related to but rather were complementary to their doctoral dissertation projects at Notre Dame, and thus provided the students with broadening experiences outside of their own areas of primary expertise. The students presented their research orally at three mini-symposia spaced throughout the summer, they wrote final research reports in the format of scientific journal articles, and they all attended and presented their research at international research conferences, either in Sweden or other European countries. The results of the students’ research have been published in 8 scientific journal articles, 1 additional paper has been submitted, and 7 of the students have completed their Ph.D. degrees to date. A direct consequence of the positive experiences that the students obtained is that two of them applied for and received postdoctoral research positions in Europe. One of the students who has completed the Ph.D. degree has accepted a position as Assistant Professor at another university starting in July 2018.

 

Although this program is now officially closed as of December 2018, professional connections are continuing among the Swedish mentors, other Ph.D. students at Notre Dame, and their dissertation mentors. An additional student plans to do research in Sweden during the coming year.

 

Another outcome of this successful program was the more recent award of a second NSF IRES grant to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Notre Dame. Having a structure similar to the first one, this second program involves students going to Germany for research. In an important change in structure, the new program provides for participation of both Ph.D. and undergraduate students. The first contingent departed for the University of Heidelberg in May of 2018, accompanied by the PI, Professor Olaf Wiest. The PI of the first program is serving as co-PI of the new program to allow for continuity of planning and follow-through with the most successful structural elements.

 

Information about these programs has been provided in materials for the recruitment of new Ph.D. students to the graduate program at Notre Dame. Some of the successfully recruited students have mentioned that these programs were positive features that attracted their interest in attending Notre Dame.
